item.title: CI/CD with GitHub Actions: Build & Push Docker Images to Docker Hub
item.description:
Hi there! Today we are going to see how to build and push a Docker image to Docker Hub, as part of your CI/CD pipeline, using GitHub Workflows.
yaml file:
name: Build and push to Dockerhub
on: push: branches: - main
jobs: push: runs-on: ubuntu-latest
steps: - name: Checkout uses: actions/checkout@v4
- name: Login uses: docker/login-action@v3.3.0 with: username: ${{ secrets.DOCKER_USERNAME }} password: ${{ secrets.DOCKER_PASSWORD }}
- name: Build and push Docker image uses: docker/build-push-action@v6.13.0 with: context: . file: ./Weather.Api/Dockerfile push: true tags: | repo-name:${{ github.sha }} repo-name/weather-api:latest
#GitHubActions #Docker
item.author: (Spyros Katsios)

item.title: ASP NET Core - Working With XML Results On Web APIs
item.description:
JSON is the way of the web API! But... What about XML? Surely we no longer need to be concerned with that?

item.title: Explicit Includes: The Art of Fetching Just Enough Data in EF Core - Chris Woody Woodruff
item.description: If you’ve ever gone grocery shopping while hungry, you know how easy it is to end up with more than you need. The same thing happens in EF Core when you’re too eager with your Include statements—you fetch all the data, even the stuff you don’t need, and suddenly, your app feels sluggish. That’s where Explicit Includes comes in, allowing you to fetch only what you need when needed, making your development process more efficient. Think of it as grocery shopping with a list, but for your code.
